text: Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast? Doctor: No, it’s here. Family Member: It’s here. Patient: Any need for a driver - chemo days, things like that? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So, on chemo days, you have to have a driver. Ummm. You may not need him. But, I mean, my sense is that if you start getting sick and nauseated, and I have to give you a medicine that’s sedating - I don’t want you getting behind the wheel of a car and driving home. Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles)

text: Patient: No. Doctor: Uh, the medicines that you take. You’re on – I thought you’re taking your, uh, apixaban or Eliquis? Five milligrams? Patient: Right. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. So, tend to see you on a Tuesday. Is everything clear? And, then we pick a day and you just go and get it. Patient: Alright. Doctor: And then that day, the people upstairs have cleared it for you. Your, uh, counts are okay. That your time is upstairs is shortened because - - Patient: I won’t have to wait for results. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?

text: Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. But chances are if you were to go on standard treatment, then yeah we’d have to wait and see what your insurance pays. Sorry about that. Family Member: That’s okay.

text: Family Member: Not to take home. Doctor: Not to take home? Okay. Patient: Not to take home. If, if they gave me some, it was in an IV. Doctor: It was in the IV. I think they did. text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: There’s uh, okay, is there any other; that was a surprise that it was larger, or that it was even there…there was a marker. Doctor: I know, yeah, the measurement totally did not indicate that. Patient: And why- Doctor: That was a shock. No, I agree with you. Patient: and that’s why – I don’t – that’s what I was trying to get at. It wasn’t there. Doctor: Yes, the reading was completely different from what actually was; you know that’s the problem, that the person reading is not the one doing the CRYO, in this case. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. So he’s the only one who would read them (papers shuffling) Patient: To see what happens, what’s going on. Doctor: Yeah, because the report - Healthcare Professional: It could switch; the report doesn’t say it helped. It didn’t say it was Doctor: No, I agree. Family Member: And to report that you got back.

text: Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
